habitat_description:
Southwest/Northwest:
This common migrant prefers high-elevation mountain ranges (Zeiner et al. 1990), where migration occurs both elevationally and geographically (NatureServer 2004). Habitat associations include alpine, bare rock/talus/scree, cliffs, grassland/herbaceous, and shrubland/chaparral (NatureServe 2004). Generally, the species prefers alpine areas, usually near snow fields or glaciers, talus, rockpiles, and cliffs (e.g., Gabrielson and Jewett 1940, Gabrielson and Lincoln 1959, Bent 1968, Kessel 1989). Typically at or above timberline (e.g., Gabrielson and Lincoln 1959, Bent 1968). In California, an elevation range of 2900m – 4300m has been reported for this species (Zeiner et al. 1990). Usually forages on open ground, among rocks on talus, and on open snow fields and glaciers (e.g., Gabrielson and Jewett 1940)(quoted directly from Macdougall-Shackleton et al. 2000). In the winter, the species utilizes pen country, including mountain meadows, shrublands, roadsides, towns, cultivated areas, rocky hillsides, margins of dry ditches (see Silloway 1903, Gabrielson and Jewett 1940, Gabrielson and Lincoln 1959, Bent 1968, Andrews and Righter 1992). Wherever bare ground, food available. Flocks usually land on ground, sometimes on buildings, occasionally in trees or bushes, fences, telephone wires (Gabrielson and Jewett 1940). May congregate at feeders if snow covers food or natural food is scarce (e.g., Andrews and Righter 1992)(quoted directly from Macdougall-Shackleton et al. 2000).
